awd_titl_txt: RAPID: Sentinel-1 and ALOS-2 InSAR interferograms to support community modeling, mapping, and estimation of hazards from strike-slip and thrust fault interactions in Haiti.
awd_abstract_narration:
This RAPID project supports the analysis of satellite data following the August 14, 2021, Haiti earthquake (M=7.2) by combining Sentinel-1 and ALOS-2 InSAR observations.  The analysis will allow preliminary interpretation of the interaction of strike-slip and thrust faults that rupture during the Haiti earthquake sequence.  Systematic release of preliminary and refined images as each new satellite pass occurs (~5-7 days) and as the aftershock sequence and supporting field work takes place. InSAR, along with aftershock relocations, will be critical to help define the fault geometry necessary for understanding the rupture and subsequent stress changes on adjacent faults. Updated images will be released right after each acquisition (https://topex.ucsd.edu/haiti_7.2/). Early distribution of these data to local field scientists informs geologic mapping that will contribute to collecting ephemeral data on surface slip. 

Higher accuracy InSAR observations produced using the GMTSAR package, with stacking and noise reduction, combining data from Sentinel-1 and ALOS-2, are critical for future modeling efforts.  The method increases the accuracy of InSAR line-of-sight (LoS) deformation maps while providing data products to help researchers identify ancillary fault structures with co- and post-seismic slip that will be constrained at large scale by available GPS data. The InSAR imagery can help resolve how significant the component of dip slip on the eastern segment of the Enriquillo Plantain Gardens Fault is and how its interaction with thrust faults is a major factor controlling this fault segmentation and thus impacts the seismic hazard in this trans-pressive boundary of the Caribbean plate.  This project will support a female graduate student who will process the images weekly.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

inst.inst_name: University of California-San Diego Scripps Inst of Oceanography

perf_inst.perf_inst_name: University of California-San Diego Scripps Inst of Oceanography

por.por_cntn:
Earthquakes pose a major threat to the people of Haiti, as tragically shown by the catastrophic M7.0, 2010 earthquake and more recently by the M7.2 2021 earthquake. These events both occurred within the Enriquillo Plantain Garden Fault Zone (EPGFZ) which runs through the southern peninsula of Haiti and is a major source of seismic hazard for the region. The objective of this project was to provide processed satellite imagery as early as possible after the 2021 earthquake to the scientific research and seismic hazard communities to learn as much as possible about the evolution of earthquake hazard following the event. The project used a technique called Interferometric Synthetic Aperture Radar (InSAR) to show how the ground was deformed during and following the event. InSAR essentially takes the difference of radar images of the ground surface before and after the earthquake. In addition to mapping the deformation due to the main shock, we provide InSAR images that show the evolution over the following two weeks of continued motion on the main fault and several faults up to 10 km away that are associated with the EPGFZ.

Broader Impacts: The information was provided to geologists and other Haitian scientists to support any field investigations, although access to the field was severely limited even to local scientists. Several meetings were held with Haitian geophysicists and international associates to provide and describe the information contained in the database and support further study. The dataset will be further analyzed in collaboration with Haitian graduate students and scientists at Facult? des Sciences Universit? d'?tat d'Ha?ti, and Laboratoire G?oazur, and will form the basis of a PhD thesis of a female graduate student at Scripps Institution of Oceanography.

We provide a database of images that can be accessed through the google earth software (https://www.google.com/earth/versions/) that is freely available and accessible to any user worldwide. The database (https://topex.ucsd.edu/haiti_7.2/index.html) contains kmz files that are easily downloaded and opened in google earth, with the original InSAR imagery and identified fault segments where motion was detected during and following  the earthquake.

 


Last Modified: 06/24/2022
Modified by: Jennifer S Haase

Image
  • (a) Overview of 2021 M7.2 and 2010 M7.0 earthquakes, aftershocks, and historic earthquakes (b) Summary of active faults based on InSAR observations. The 2021 rupture is shown in red, 2021 postseismic slip in green, 2010 postseismic slip in dotted white, and secondary fault features in orange.
    H.Z. Yin
    Copyright owner is an institution with an existing agreement allowing use by NSF
    Jennifer S Haase
    Fault features of the 2010 and 2021 Haiti earthquakes.
